key_insight: Deep generative models that produce intermediate physical states (surface-current maps) instead of device layouts enable more stable, physically consistent inverse design for tunable and stacked metasurfaces.
problem_solved: Directly mapping target electromagnetic responses to metasurface layouts is ill-posed and unstable—especially for tunable and multi-layer designs. The paper stabilizes inverse design by learning a physically meaningful intermediate representation that regularizes solutions and improves robustness and generalization.
method: Train a conditional deep generative model to produce surface-current maps conditioned on target electromagnetic responses and tuning parameters.
Use a differentiable forward model or surrogate to map generated surface currents to predicted electromagnetic outputs and (optionally) to convert currents into realizable layout patterns.
Exploit structured latent priors and interpolation in current-space to enable stable design for stacked/tunable metasurfaces and to resolve non-uniqueness.
impact: Provides an ML-friendly recipe for physics-guided inverse design: using intermediate physical states improves stability, interpretability, and sample efficiency, and can be applied to other inverse problems in computational physics and engineering.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: target response → generative model (latent) → surface-current map → forward solver → layout/verification.
Performance comparison chart: stability/accuracy vs direct-layout methods (error bars, failure modes).
Schematic of a stacked/tunable metasurface with annotated layer-wise currents and control parameters.
Latent-space visualization: interpolation trajectories showing smooth, physically plausible transitions between designs.
paper_title: Learning intermediate physical states for inverse metasurface design
